bibl.title: Letter from S.S. Goldwater to Albert E. Truby, May 1, 1935

div1.p: Goldwater informs Truby that he will not have a job opening in his hospital.

div1.head: Letter from S.S. Goldwater to Albert E. Truby, May 1, 1935
div1.opener:
DEPARTMENT OF HOSPITALS
City of New York.
May 1, 1935.
S. S. Goldwater, M.D.
Commissioner.
Brigadier General Albert E. Truby, M.C.
United States Army Medical Center
Washington, D. C.
Dear General Truby:
div1.p:
Notwithstanding my expectations to the contrary, I have just
been informed that there will be no break in the ranks of my deputies this
year, which means of course that I have unintentionally put you and your
friends to considerable trouble without profit to any body except that the
incident has given me an opportunity to become acquainted with you.

It may interest you to know that I have received and am placing
on file letters of unusual laudatory character from General Ireland, General
Russell, Colonel Reynolds and Dr. Kopotsky. If you prefer to have these
letters in your own files, I shall be glad to send the originals to you, re-
taining copies for the files of the Department of Hospitals.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours signed
S. S. GOLDWATER, M. D.
C o m m i s s i o n e r SSG-dz
